problem: Given the functions $h(x) = 2x + 3$ and $j(x) = x^3 - 1$, find the value of $h(j(-2))$.
solution: First, calculate $j(-2)$ by substituting $-2$ into the function $j$: $j(-2) = (-2)^3 - 1 = -8 - 1 = -9$. Next, substitute $-9$ into the function $h$: $h(-9) = 2(-9) + 3 = -18 + 3 = -15$. Thus, $h(j(-2)) = \boxed{-15}$.
